text.headline: Airborne/Aerosol: Old problem, new challenge!
text.text:
SARS-CoV-2 transmission: a inconsistency/ambiguity?
No authorities have admitted airborne transmission yet.
But all national and international authorities recommended maintaining good ventilation. If not airborne, why ventilate? - Yuguo Li

media.caption: Pringle - Observations on the diseases of the army (1753).

text.headline: Fresh air known to be important for army medical camps
text.text: As long ago as 1753, Pringle, a doctor, studied medical army camp hospitals. He found that fresh air was important to stop disease spread. post (@jmcrookston) and also this (@jmcrookston)

media.caption: Modern surgical mask Ben Frankin would've worn if he could

text.headline: Ben Franklin knew the score!
text.text:
Writeup: Dr Benjamin Franklin is seemingly predicting airborne viruses responsible for influenza and others associated with the common cold, and drawing a connection to becoming clinically ill with poor dietary choices (2017 writeup; see also Benjamin Franklin Would Get Social Distancing).

He also said in 1785 'I am persuaded that no common Air from without, is so unwholesome as the Air within a close Room, that has been often breath'd and not changed.', which you can find here

text.headline: Fresh air again referred to as important
text.text: Fodere, in his treatise Lecons sur les epidemies, noted that fresh air in hospitals was important. Part of the text in this picture reads 'Make hospitals well isolated, well aired, with many air currents produced by ventilators and don't fill it with a large number of ill patients ...' post here (@jmcrookston)

media.caption: Charles Chapin - Methods for the prevention of scarlet fever (1888)

text.headline: Charles Chapin knew scarlet fever was occasionally airborne
text.text: Charles Chapin, who would later promote that most transmission was droplet borne, appreciated that scarlet fever could occasionally infect someone on the second floor of a house from the first - it was therefore airborne. His book. post (@jmcrookston)

media.caption: Charles Chapin MD - Sources and modes of infection (1910)

text.headline: Chapin proposed that pathogens live in our bodies and are transmitted from person to person
text.text: Charles Chapin, medical doctor in Rhode Island, proposed in his groundbreaking book the radical notion that pathogens don't live long outside the body and were therefore transmitted person to person, and not simply freely floating in the air (miasma theory). He focussed therefore on stopping chains of transmission. Because he saw most transmission happening at short-range, which he called 'close contact', he suggested it was reasonable to him that this meant diseases were transmitted by droplets. He is wrong about this last part but the rest was brilliant. As an aside, he did not think fomites account for much transmission.

media.caption: Wells curves for different relative humidity

text.headline: W. F. Wells founding the droplet nuclei science in 1934
text.text: Wells thought that droplets smaller a certain size would quickly evaporate, leaving a dry residue that drifts in the air. Since droplets from an infected person may contain infectious bacteria or viruses, these processes influence transmission of respiratory diseases

text.headline: Guinea pigs proof of airborne transmission of Tuberculosis (TB)
text.text: Richard L. Riley - first hand account of 1962 proof by Riley, Mills, O'Grady, Sultan, Willstadt, Shivpuri, and Wells: 'Infectiousness of air from a tuberculosis ward'. That study: here

text.headline: Airborne infection: Flu too
text.text: Riley studied the airborne nature of respiratory diseases in the middle of the 20th century, and published many times. See also a COVID19 era article on Riley.

text.headline: One child infects seven in a physician's office
text.text: Measles outbreak in a pediatric practice: airborne transmission in an office setting. The study goes on to warn of modern office buildings having recirculated air measles thread (@jmcrookston)

text.headline: Three children catch measles at doctor's office an hour after the index patient left
text.text: Three children caught measles at a doctor's office. They were there an hour after the sick child left. measles thread (@jmcrookston)

text.headline: EXPOSURE TO MEASLES FEARED AT SPORTS EVENT
text.text: Thousands of people involved in the International Special Olympics last month may have been exposed to measles, one of the most easily transmitted communicable diseases, according to the Minnesota Health Department. measles thread (@jmcrookston)

text.text:
This study confirms the importance of vomiting in the transmission
of NLV and provides evidence that direct infection with aerosolized viral particles occurs

text.headline: Study: Ninth floor guests at the Metropole Hotel catch SARS. Index may have vomited in hall
text.text: Twenty-one infected by one guest who vomited in a corridor. Excerpt: "... At the time, it was not clear if the causative agent was being transmitted by airborne particles, as measles and tuberculosis spread ..."

media.caption: Measured airflow rates at different ward locations

text.headline: Study: Possible Role of Aerosol Transmission in a Hospital Outbreak of Influenza
text.text: Conclusions: Our findings suggest a possible role of aerosol transmission of influenza in an acute ward setting. Source and engineering controls, such as avoiding aerosol generation and improving ventilation design, may warrant consideration to prevent nosocomial outbreaks.
